addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

Ult
o
May
1590
. M
r
Bodeley to my L. from
e
Haghe
.
Groninghen
./

page.lettertext:
fol.199r
It may please yo
r
L. to be advertised that
I have receaved by
Persival
her
Ma
ties
letters,
and one from yo
r
L. and I have made her Ma
ties
excuse both to
e
Councel
and to
Count William
,
for
at their letters were not answeared. But
because I am acquainted w
t
their over suspicious
and imagining humo
rs
, I feare they will sur-
mise, there is some mater in
at silence, that will
turne to their prejudice. Count William,
who is nowe in
Friseland
, is sent unto from hens,
to declare his opinion for o
r
further proceeding.
The siege of
Nieumeghen
is a lette unto us. For
it is not thought expedient, that her Ma
ties
letters
should be sent into Groeninghen, but when we can
present sufficient forces before
e towne, of the
Englishe nation in speciall,
e better to concure
in c
o
firmation of
e letters, and to adde a greater
courage to her Ma
ties
frindes, who are thought to be
so many among
e inhabitants, as we are in good
hope, if faire meanes faile, to winne
e towne
perforce. Howbeit at this present, almost
all
e forces of these contreis, that may be drawen
to
e feelde, are before Nieumeghen, from whens
they can not well be spared, till their fortifi-
cations be ended, about 3 weekes hens. I
have also written to my frindes in Embden, to
give them notice of
e letter, to make
e way
more easie. For though I have had good assistance
of Persival, in respect of his adventures, and
of his travel too and fro, and also otherwise, yet
e minister of Embden
Mentius
, and one
Joest
van Cleve
, in time past a burgmaster of Groe-
ninghen, have bin farre greater instruments: and
fol.199v
what other meanes have bin used, to bring the
mater to this passe, it would be too tedious to
discourse unto yo
r
L. It was not possible
to accomplishe her Ma
ties
desire, to have it secretly
caried. For when her Hig
nes
refused to take
e
enterprise uppon her, there could nothing be done
w
t
out
e privitie and liking of
e Councel of state,
e
States of Frise
, and Count William. Besides
the opinion is heere,
at
e mater being published,
it hath made a great preparation among many,
whiche
e Enemies forces can by no meanes im-
peache. In my last to yo
r
L. I signified
that, whiche was written to
is Councel, as well
as to my self, that
e Spanishe Councel of Groe-
ninghen was willed to depart, and that the
towne was in Parle w
t
e States of Frise. We
are sins informed, that there was a publicke con-
ference, and hostages delivered, but it con-
cerned only an agreement, about
e exchange
of prisonners: and some were expelled
e towne,
but men of meaner qualitie then Counsello
rs
.
We are at this present advertised by
Count William, that
Verdugo
hath failed of a
late attempt,
at he made, to enter perforce the
towne of Groeninghen, and to have put in Garri-
son, whereto he had many assistants w
t
in
e towne,
whiche being notified hath put
e place in a great
garboile. There is at this present a
certaine agreement made between
Count Maurice
and Count William, w
t
consent of
e Councel of
state,
at Count William assisting Count Maurice
w
t
all his forces of Friselande, in
e siege of Nieu-
meghen, he shall after be assisted by Count Mau-
rice, w
t
all
e forces of these quarters, in the en-
terprise of Groeninghen.
fol.200r
At Nieumeghen there hath bin nothing yet
exploited, on ether side. O
r
fortifications
goe forward, w
ch
notw
t
standing
e Enemie
hath endevoured to disturbe, w
t
shotte of great
artillerie, but prevailing nothing, it is sup-
posed,
at he doth but seeke to furnishe
e towne
w
t
souldiers and victuals, and will after passe
e Rhine, to assault some townes of
Guelderl
a
d
,
thereby to divert o
r
forces from Nieumeghen.
There have bin letters of
e Enemie
lately intercepted, written from
Collen
to
Zut-
phen
,
Deventer
, and other places: of w
ch
I send
yo
r
L.
e copie of one,
e rest contening
mater to like effect. The occur-
rences heere doe not signifie as yet of any
succo
rs
sent from
e
D. of Parma
to those of
e
Ligue
, the souldiers being unwilling to marche,
unles they may be paied for 3 monethes before
hand, and goe w
t
greater forces, then
e Duke
hath yet appointed: w
ch
we can not learne to
be more then 800 hourse, and 2500 foote: w
ch
many men conjecture this enterprise of Nieu-
meghen will divert uppon o
r
selves.
Certaine troupes of
Breda
, have defeated of
late 120 lances of
e Enemie, of w
ch
they
tooke 30 prisoners, and towardes 500 head of
beast. Nowe
at
e Enemie is occupied els
where, it is thought convenient,
at we shoul d at-
tempt
e revictualling of Breda, whiche ether
succeeded or failed yesterday.
From
e Hage.
31 May A
o
90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden.
Tho. Bodley.
O
r
Letters out of
Zeland
report for certaine that
Richardot
is come to
Brussels
,
and hath c
o
mission to offer
large conditions of peace.
